thread.title: U.S. Stocks Lower on Earnings, Data
thread.title_full: U.S. Stocks Lower on Earnings, Data

author: morningstar.com
title: U.S. Stocks Lower on Earnings, Data
text:
By Leslie Josephs and Tommy Stubbington
U.S. stocks' losses deepened Wednesday after a gloomy earnings forecast from Wal-Mart Stores Inc. weighed on shares of consumer-focused companies.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 101 points, or 0.5% to 16983. Wal-Mart tumbled 9.1% to $60.65.
The retailer surprised investors by predicting a sharp drop in earnings next year, citing in large part its pledge to raise wages for most U.S. workers and efforts to lift online sales.
Wal-Mart's tumble shaved 41 points off the Dow.
The S&P 500 was down 0.1% at 2001.2, but the S&P consumer staples index fell 0.8%. The Nasdaq Composite was up 0.2%.
Wal-Mart's announcement came after data showing weaker-than-expected U.S. retail sales growth of 0.1% in September.
"The strength of the consumer in the U.S....is being questioned," said Kate Warne, investment strategist at Edward Jones.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury note dropped below 2% for the first time in two weeks as demand for haven assets rose. Yields fall as prices rise.
Investors were also grappling with mixed earnings reports.
J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. shares dropped 2.6% at $59.53 after the bank missed analysts' third-quarter estimates. J.P. Morgan reported after market close on Tuesday.
Bank of America Corp. shares rose 0.8% to $15.65 after the bank beat analysts' expectations for third-quarter earnings. TripAdvisor Inc. shares surged 25% to trade at $83.39 after Priceline Group Inc. agreed to list some of its travel websites on TripAdvisor.
The U.S. economy continued to expand at a modest pace at the end of the third quarter, though activity slowed or declined in some pockets as the stronger dollar weighed on some employers, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday European shares followed Asian markets lower after data showed lower-than-expected Chinese inflation in September, a day after disappointing import and export data from China dented stocks around the world. The consumer-price index rose 1.6% in September from a year earlier, compared with a 2% rise in August.
The Stoxx Europe 600 fell 0.7%, deepening losses from Tuesday.
Most Asian indexes declined amid fears Beijing would miss its year-end growth target. The Shanghai Composite Index closed 0.9% lower, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index lost 0.7% and Japan's Nikkei Stock Average fell 1.9%. China's third-quarter growth figures are due for release on Monday.
Chinese markets had initially rallied as the data propped up expectations for new stimulus measures, though the optimism quickly waned.
"Fears of imminent financial catastrophe were overdone. But most people see that the growth capacity of the global economy probably diminished over the summer," said Guy Foster, head of research at wealth manager Brewin Dolphin.
In currencies, the euro rose 0.5% against the dollar to $1.1445, while the dollar was 0.5% lower against the yen at Yen119.13.
In commodities, gold prices climbed 0.8% to $1,174.60 a troy ounce.
Brent crude oil was down 0.3% at $49.67 a barrel.
Write to Leslie Josephs at leslie.josephs@wsj.com and Tommy Stubbington at tommy.stubbington@wsj.com
(END) Dow Jones Newswires
October 14, 2015 14:27 ET (18:27
